tags: excerpt from a book I'll never write
excerpt from a story i'll never write
summary:
there’s sunlight tracing her skin 
because everywhere she is 
that’s how the light gets in 

 
and there’s a bravery I get when...
text:
there’s sunlight tracing her skin
because everywhere she is
that’s how the light gets in 


and there’s a bravery I get when she whispers “hello”
like the world is conquerable
and I am just steps from being crowned 


so when people ask who saved me from drowning 
I have to be honest and say “myself”
but I couldn’t have done without her help 


and there is ink staining the pages of the histories
and they spell out here her name 
because she is flowers and freedom, sugar and spite 


the stars twinkle in her eyes
and the sun has met it’s match in her grin
oh, let me tell the the constellations they have nothing on her
source: roses and thorns, she is by Abby S

reblog.comment: roses and thorns, she is by Abby S

summary: I love looking at all the fan theories and seeing how they ALL are underestimating Sansa. Using words like “unlikely” or “not...
body: I love looking at all the fan theories and seeing how they ALL are underestimating Sansa. Using words like “unlikely” or “not important enough”. I’m so ready for her to absolutely blow their f***ing minds with how she kills it in this next and final season. People have been underestimating her this whole series and I can’t wait for it to blow up in their faces…. 🤘🏻🖤🐺

summary: Hi! What do you think Sansa and Brienne's relationship will be like next season?
question: Hi! What do you think Sansa and Brienne's relationship will be like next season?
answer: I think that it will continue to be as it has been thus far, which is essentially the relationship between a lady and her sworn sword. Every time they interacted thus far, it’s through that lens. Brienne’s role in Sansa’s storyline essentially consist of protecting her and following her orders. The show has not been interesting in doing much else with their relationships and I am quite disappointing. Personally, I would have enjoyed them becoming friends, being comfortable with each other, and having deep one on one conversations that isn’t related to work. There would still be a power imbalance, but the show is quite lacking in friendships between two women, and even more so for women who are of equal stature in rank (That’s not the case here, but that’s better than what we have thus far). I think it would have been great for Brienne to be the person that Sansa could be emotionally vulnerable with, all while having Sansa be the person that Brienne showcase her softer side to.

summary: “Some people will always need help. That doesn't mean they’re not worth helping.” - Meera Reed   Like many of you, I’ve heard...
body:
“Some people will always need help. That doesn’t mean they’re not worth helping.” - Meera Reed 

Like many of you, I’ve heard how “weak”, “useless” and “feeble” Sansa is. The teaser for s8 where Jon and Arya pull out their swords and Sansa is standing between them fueled this Sansa beat down. Personally, I think it’s simply an excuse because many just don’t like her character. How else can we look at the yearly predictions that “Sansa will betray Jon/betray the Starks!”? People don’t trust her because of what she did as an 11 y.o. (12 or 13 on the show). When she was naive, ignorant and didn’t know NOT to trust the adults around her. 

But it still frustrates me, makes me shake my head and sometimes get pissed off. This character, even though she is proving herself through her wits and cunning more and more each book/season, can’t catch a break. 

Meera said the above quote in regards to Jojen. I thought it was kind of ironic that Osha asked if it wasn’t embarrassing that Jojen had to depend upon his sis her for protection when these guys all needed some protection. Even a 7 foot something man with giants blood needed her help.

Sansa may need people with swords to protect her person, but they need her as well. While they’re training and drawing up battle plans, she’s coordinating with other houses to stockpile food, supplies and anything else they’ll need when they come to Winterfell. She is thinking about the politics behind her and Jon’s actions because she knows almost everyone around. She makes sure that the blacksmiths, the stable hands, the kitchen and everyone at Winterfell are doing their jobs. Who else would be doing these things otherwise? 

Oh, and other people who may need help in s8 but I don’t hear them being called “weak”, “useless”, etc. because they don’t use a sword.

Isn’t what Sansa is doing JUST as important as what Varys or Missandei are doing? I would argue moreso, but maybe that’s my bias. 

I think Meera’s quote was supposed to be about Jojen And Bran and Hodor but also for others like Sansa. Who some in the fandom just LOVE to trash.

tags: a song of ice and fire
also yes sansa thinks arya as being an unsatisfactory sister when she thinks she is dead
but arya calls everything sansa likes/does/wabt stupid when she thinks sansa is a captive and when she thinks sansa is dead as well
your petty internal feelings don't just magically go away when someone dies or something bad happens to them
you can feel sympathy and sad about it but whatever that person made you feel...you'ld still think about it when you think of that person
i didn't address that in the ask because it didn't fit
the question of whether sansa loves arya belongs to another ask so i didn't address it here either
summary: Hi I’m a different anon then from before. I really like Sansa but Arya is my fav. I mostly understand all of her actions and...
question: Hi I’m a different anon then from before. I really like Sansa but Arya is my fav. I mostly understand all of her actions and they are justifiable considering the position that she was in and her age so I don’t judge her for any of that. The one thing that kind of made me sad though was when Sansa was thinking of Arya and thought she was unsatisfactory as sisters went. I thought it was a bit harsh for her baby sister that could very well be dead. Do you think she loves or cares about Arya?
answer:
When Sansa thought that Arya was unsatisfactory as sisters went, I thought that it was valid for her to feel in such a way. Think about it, Sansa has three high born brothers and a half-brother, and they all do and prefer traditionally masculine activities. They train alongside each other and they enjoy the same hobbies, so they do these together as well. They have a sibling that they can not only relate to when it comes to having a similar daily life, but a sibling they can do what they love with. Then you have Sansa, who loves to sew, to dance, to sing, to play instruments, to read and write, to dress prettily, to listen to romantic stories, etc. A sister in the traditional sense of the word would in theory not only be good at all of these things, but more importantly, would enjoy to do them alongside Sansa. They could gossip, eat lemon cakes and and listen to stories of knightly valor together. 

This is where Arya comes in. Arya is her little sister. In theory, she’s supposed to be the only member of the Stark household who she could do all of these activities in a daily level with. She’s supposed to enjoy courtesies, enjoy gossiping, enjoy these romantic tales, enjoy these things that none of her other siblings even pretend to care about. However, Arya not only doesn’t but acts in a way that doesn’t fit with these conventions, and far prefers to do the same things that her brothers do. Not only that but all of her siblings collectively look down on what Sansa likes and wants. Jon has an extremely misogynistic view of the struggles of traditionally feminine women and is quick to dismiss them, Robb doesn’t put as much value to his sisters as he does on Jaime, Bran has no wish to hang out with Arya and Sansa in the beginning of the series because they are girls, and later mocks the romantic stories that Sansa likes, and internally Arya consistently degrades everything that Sansa does, likes and wants. Not only do her siblings not enjoy the things that she does, but they look down on her for enjoying these things. 

 The moment that Sansa is thinking about how Arya is an unsatisfactory sister, she doesn’t mean that Arya is an unsatisfactory sibling and that she particularly dislikes her, but rather that she doesn’t do the conventional things that Sansa would come to expect from a sister in that society and so Sansa is often alone with the few friends that she has (who can’t always be there to hang out with her). Sansa felt very lonely in Winterfell because of the limited amount of people she could relate to there, and there wasn’t a wide outlet to enjoy all of the things that she liked. For example, singers don’t often go North, nor are there tourneys there and songs and tourneys are two things that Sansa actively enjoy a lot.  The quote about ‘’unsatisfactory sister’’ is especially important in relation to Margaery. She is someone Sansa immediately became attached to because she offered Sansa the opportunity to have a sibling that she could do all of these traditionally feminine things with. Even earlier in the series, Sansa laments the fact that she never got a sister she could relate to and do things she loves with. She often tries to include Arya or asks her to join her in doing something, but Arya either doesn’t realize it, or flat out just doesn’t want to do what Sansa wants to do. The contrary is just as valid. Arya proposed for Sansa to join her and Mycah but Sansa does not because she doesn’t particularly enjoy the things that Arya often wants to do. Both are unwilling to compromise, but while Arya has other siblings she could do what she loves with (plus she interacts a lot with the small folk), Sansa does not have a sibling like that, and has very few friends. Her loneliness in Winterfell perfectly explains her wanting to leave that place and her wishing to have a traditionally feminine sibling.

reblog.comment:
When Sansa thought that Arya was unsatisfactory as sisters went, I thought that it was valid for her to feel in such a way. Think about it, Sansa has three high born brothers and a half-brother, and they all do and prefer traditionally masculine activities. They train alongside each other and they enjoy the same hobbies, so they do these together as well. They have a sibling that they can not only relate to when it comes to having a similar daily life, but a sibling they can do what they love with. Then you have Sansa, who loves to sew, to dance, to sing, to play instruments, to read and write, to dress prettily, to listen to romantic stories, etc. A sister in the traditional sense of the word would in theory not only be good at all of these things, but more importantly, would enjoy to do them alongside Sansa. They could gossip, eat lemon cakes and and listen to stories of knightly valor together. 

This is where Arya comes in. Arya is her little sister. In theory, she’s supposed to be the only member of the Stark household who she could do all of these activities in a daily level with. She’s supposed to enjoy courtesies, enjoy gossiping, enjoy these romantic tales, enjoy these things that none of her other siblings even pretend to care about. However, Arya not only doesn’t but acts in a way that doesn’t fit with these conventions, and far prefers to do the same things that her brothers do. Not only that but all of her siblings collectively look down on what Sansa likes and wants. Jon has an extremely misogynistic view of the struggles of traditionally feminine women and is quick to dismiss them, Robb doesn’t put as much value to his sisters as he does on Jaime, Bran has no wish to hang out with Arya and Sansa in the beginning of the series because they are girls, and later mocks the romantic stories that Sansa likes, and internally Arya consistently degrades everything that Sansa does, likes and wants. Not only do her siblings not enjoy the things that she does, but they look down on her for enjoying these things. 

 The moment that Sansa is thinking about how Arya is an unsatisfactory sister, she doesn’t mean that Arya is an unsatisfactory sibling and that she particularly dislikes her, but rather that she doesn’t do the conventional things that Sansa would come to expect from a sister in that society and so Sansa is often alone with the few friends that she has (who can’t always be there to hang out with her). Sansa felt very lonely in Winterfell because of the limited amount of people she could relate to there, and there wasn’t a wide outlet to enjoy all of the things that she liked. For example, singers don’t often go North, nor are there tourneys there and songs and tourneys are two things that Sansa actively enjoy a lot.  The quote about ‘’unsatisfactory sister’’ is especially important in relation to Margaery. She is someone Sansa immediately became attached to because she offered Sansa the opportunity to have a sibling that she could do all of these traditionally feminine things with. Even earlier in the series, Sansa laments the fact that she never got a sister she could relate to and do things she loves with. She often tries to include Arya or asks her to join her in doing something, but Arya either doesn’t realize it, or flat out just doesn’t want to do what Sansa wants to do. The contrary is just as valid. Arya proposed for Sansa to join her and Mycah but Sansa does not because she doesn’t particularly enjoy the things that Arya often wants to do. Both are unwilling to compromise, but while Arya has other siblings she could do what she loves with (plus she interacts a lot with the small folk), Sansa does not have a sibling like that, and has very few friends. Her loneliness in Winterfell perfectly explains her wanting to leave that place and her wishing to have a traditionally feminine sibling.
